node.text:
Let’s talk ABGs⁣
⁣
💉ABG = arterial blood gas💉⁣
⁣
An ABG test measures the acidity/pH and the levels of oxygen & carbon dioxide from an artery⁣
⁣
Why would we test this? 🤔⁣
To assess the function of the pt’s lungs and how well they are able to move O2 into the blood and remove CO2⁣
⁣
✅NORMAL PH: 7.35-7.45⁣
If pH is less than 7.35 = acidosis⁣
If pH is greater than 7.45 = alkalosis⁣
⁣
✅NORMAL CO2: 35-45⁣
The CO2 reading tells you if the problem is a respiratory issue or not⁣
⁣
✅NORMAL HCO3/BICARB: 22-26⁣
The bicarb reading tells you if the problem is a metabolic issue or not⁣
⁣
👉🏼ANALYZING ABGS:⁣
1. Is pH acidic or alkalodic? If <7.35 = acidosis, if >7.45 = alkalosis⁣
2. Is the problem Respiratory or Metabolic? In respiratory disorders, the pH and PaCO2 change in opposite directions (high pH, low CO2; low pH, high CO2). In metabolic disorders the pH and PaCO2 change in the same direction (high pH, high HCO3; low pH, low HCO3). ROME (respiratory = opposite, metabolic = equal)⁣
3. Compensation? Usually, compensation does not return the pH to normal (7.35 – 7.45). No compensation = one of CO2 or bicarb is normal. Full compensation = pH is normal⁣
⁣

node.text:
Here’s an NG tube tip for every nursing student and new grad 👌🏼⁣
⁣
LIKE & SAVE THIS VID FOR FUTURE REFERENCE 🥰

Rundown of my favourite @wearfigs styles, my sizing/recommendations, and a quick Q+A because I get asked about them almost daily!⁣
⁣
If you don’t want to watch the full video:⁣
⁣
My coupon code➡️ figsxbarbara⁣
⁣
👚 Fave styles = Catarina top, Yola bottoms, Zamora Jogger bottoms⁣
⁣
👩🏽‍⚕️ My sizing = I’m about 5’6 + 113 lbs, normally wear an XS/0/24 or 25. I wear a size XXS in my scrubs (tips & bottoms). I could probably get away with sizing up to an XS in the Yola bottoms but otherwise, the XXS in the top + jogger bottom fit great⁣
⁣
❓Do they shrink with wash? No⁣
❓If I’m in between sizes, what should I do? Personally, I’d choose the larger size.. nothing worse than working 12 hrs in something too tight⁣
❓Shipping to Canada? Yep!! All of the duties + shipping are shown to you before you pay - there’s no surprise at your doorstep. And yes, the company is working on lowering this cost for us Canadians!⁣
❓Do they last? Yep, I’ve been wearing some pairs for over 2.5 years now :)⁣

node.text: My top 10 tips when it comes to NCLEX studying! 👩🏽‍⚕️📚

node.title: PASS THE NCLEX ON YOUR FIRST TRY

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Barbara | BSN, RN on August 28, 2021 tagging @nurseiq. May be an image of 1 person, standing and indoor.

node.text:
NCLEX NEED-TO-KNOW⁣
⁣
➖MATERNITY➖⁣
👉🏼FAB 9 : Folic acid = B9. Hint: B stands for brain (decreases the incidence of neural tube defects); the pt should begin taking B9 three months prior to becoming pregnant.⁣
👉🏼TORCHS syndrome in the neonate : This is a combination of diseases. These include toxoplasmosis, rubella (German measles), cytomegalovirus, herpes, and syphyllis. Pregnant nurses should not be assigned to care for the client with toxoplasmosis or cytomegalovirus.⁣
⁣
➖ADULT HEALTH➖⁣
👉🏼Treatment for sickle cell crises : HHOP (heat, hydration, oxygen, pain medications)⁣
👉🏼Hip fractures commonly hemorrhage, whereas femur fractures are at risk for fat emboli⁣
👉🏼5 Ps of fractures and compartment syndrome— These are symptoms of fractures and compartment syndrome: pain, pallor, pulselessness, parenthesis, polar (cold)⁣
⁣
➖DELEGATION➖⁣
👉🏼The PN, like the RN, can monitor pt’s with IV therapy, insert urinary catheters and feeding tubes, apply restraints, discontinue IVs, drains, and sutures.⁣
👉🏼Delegate sterile skills such as dressing changes to the RN or LPN. Where nonskilled care is required, you can delegate the stable pt to the nursing assistant. Choose the most critical pt to assign to the RN, such as the pt who has recently returned from chest surgery. Pt’s who are being discharged should have final assessments done by the RN.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Barbara | BSN, RN on August 26, 2021.

node.text:
🚨RAYNAUD’S DISEASE🚨⁣
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⁣
I remember getting a question about Raynaud’s incorrect on one of my first nursing school tests, so this post goes out to anyone currently studying this topic - I hope you get any future Raynaud questions correct after reading this post!⁣
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⁣
What exactly is this disease?⁣
👉🏼Its a cardiac issue where there is vasospasm of arterioles and arteries - the vasospasm causes constriction of cutaneous vessels (usually seen in the fingers, toes, and ears)⁣
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⁣
What will you see during an assessment?⁣
👉🏼Blanching, followed by cyanosis during the vasoconstriction. The tissue will then turn red when the vasospasm is relieved. The pt may state that they feel numbness, tingling, swelling, and a cold temperature at the affected area⁣
⁣
What can you do in this scenario?⁣
👉🏼Monitor peripheral pulses, administer vasodilators as ordered, teach the pt about precipitating factors (e.g. cold, stress), instruct the pt to avoid smoking, and teach the pt to wear warm clothing/socks/gloves in cold weather

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Barbara | BSN, RN on August 20, 2021 tagging @nurseiq. May be an image of 1 person, standing and indoor.

node.text:
🧠NEURO ASSESSMENT🧠⁣⁣
⁣⁣
When doing a focused neuro assessment, make sure you’re covering:⁣⁣
Mental status + speech⁣⁣
Cranial nerve function⁣⁣
Sensory function⁣⁣
Motor function⁣⁣
Reflexes⁣⁣
⁣⁣
1️⃣𝐌𝐄𝐍𝐓𝐀𝐋 𝐒𝐓𝐀𝐓𝐔𝐒 + 𝐒𝐏𝐄𝐄𝐂𝐇⁣⁣
A+Ox4? __⁣⁣
LOC (alert, lethargic, comatose) __⁣⁣
Appearance + behaviour __⁣⁣
Speech (pace, volume, clarity, spontaneity) __⁣⁣
Cognitive function (memory, judgment, emotional status) __⁣⁣
Glasgow Coma Scale __⁣⁣
⁣⁣
2️⃣𝐂𝐑𝐀𝐍𝐈𝐀𝐋 𝐍𝐄𝐑𝐕𝐄 𝐅𝐔𝐍𝐂𝐓𝐈𝐎𝐍 ⁣⁣
Assess 12 cranial nerves __⁣⁣
⁣⁣
3️⃣𝐒𝐄𝐍𝐒𝐎𝐑𝐘 𝐅𝐔𝐍𝐂𝐓𝐈𝐎𝐍⁣⁣
Assess for: pain, light touch, vibration, position, and discrimination⁣⁣
⁣⁣
4️⃣𝐌𝐎𝐓𝐎𝐑 𝐅𝐔𝐍𝐂𝐓𝐈𝐎𝐍⁣⁣
Muscle tone (passive ROM) __⁣⁣
Muscle strength (have pt move major muscle group against resistance) __⁣⁣
Cerebellum assessment (coordination/balance when sitting + standing) __⁣⁣
⁣⁣
5️⃣𝐑𝐄𝐅𝐋𝐄𝐗𝐄𝐒⁣⁣
Deep tendon reflexes (graded 0 to +4; normal is +2) __⁣⁣
Superficial reflexes (Babinski reflex is abnormal) __⁣⁣
⁣⁣
To be honest - when I’m doing a neuro assessment, I stick to assessing mental status, sensory (usually only using pain stimuli) and motor function! 👩🏽‍⚕️ I actually haven’t seen a full cranial nerve assessment done at the bedside - have you??⁣

node.text:
STUDY TIPS FOR MY NEW NURSING STUDENTS⁣
⁣⁣⁣
✍🏼𝐌𝐀𝐊𝐈𝐍𝐆 𝐍𝐎𝐓𝐄𝐒✍🏼⁣⁣⁣
Transfer your PPT slides to a 📄 word doc 1-2 days before lecture (I show you how to easily do this in my IGTV)⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Using the PPT as a guideline, go through the assigned reading📕 for that week. Add in any additional info from the reading into your word doc⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
On the day of lecture, have your word doc open and bold anything in your notes that the prof mentions several time💻 (this is probably a test question/topic)⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
📚𝐒𝐓𝐔𝐃𝐘𝐈𝐍𝐆 𝐅𝐎𝐑 𝐓𝐄𝐒𝐓📚⁣⁣⁣
Print off your word doc, highlight key points, and hand draw any diagrams necessary✏️ (I used to watch YouTube videos or Khan Academy🙌🏽 for additional study resources - I drew out key diagrams from these videos on my printed word doc)⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Find a study method that works for you - cue cards, reading your notes out loud, pretend to teach a class about the topic, group study sessions, listening to lecture recordings, Youtube videos, writing out the concept over and over... once you find a method that works - STICK WITH IT👩🏽‍⚕️⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Use mnemonics when memorizing lists of things✅ (e.g. S/S of a disease, side effects of a drug, etc.)⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Practice answering questions once you’re done reviewing!! This is a great way to test your knowledge🧠. Usually there are practice questions at the end of every chapter in your textbook⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Buy the Saunders NCLEX book📙 - this book does a great job of providing an overview of every topic you’ll cover in school. It covers KEY points (these points are most likely to appear on a test)⁣⁣

May be an image of 3 people and text that says 'Placenta PLACENTA PREVIA Umbilical cord Uterus Fetus Cervix Normal placenta Lọw-lying placenta Placenta previa babycenter ABRUPTIO PLACENTAE Placenta detached from uterus Blood clot Uterus Placenta detached from uterus External bleeding babycenter'.

node.text:
Placenta Complications⤵️
⁣⁣
𝘗𝘓𝘈𝘊𝘌𝘕𝘛𝘈 𝘗𝘙𝘌𝘝𝘐𝘈⁣
➡️Placenta implanted low in uterus or over cervical os⁣⁣
🩺S/S: sudden painless, bright red bleeding⁣⁣
👩🏽‍⚕️Priorities: Ultrasound to confirm, avoid vaginal exam, side lying position, monitor amount of blood, IV fluids and blood products, C-section may be needed⁣⁣
⁣⁣
𝘈𝘉𝘙𝘜𝘗𝘛𝘐𝘖 𝘗𝘓𝘈𝘊𝘌𝘕𝘛𝘈𝘌⁣⁣
➡️Premature separation of placenta from wall⁣⁣
🩺S/S: painful dark red bleeding, uterine pain, uterine rigidity, abdo pain⁣⁣
👩🏽‍⚕️Priorities: Trendelenburg position, monitor bleeding, O2, IV fluids, blood products, prep for delivery ASAP

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Barbara | BSN, RN on August 11, 2021.

node.text:
CHEST TUBE🤓⁣
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⁣
What is it?⁣
👩🏽‍⚕️ A tube inserted into the pleural space, which allows for blood, fluid💦, or air 🌬to drain and therefore allowing the lung to re-inflate⁣
⁣
What conditions 🤕 require chest tube insertion?⁣
👩🏽‍⚕️Pneumothorax - air leak in the pleural space, causing the lung to collapse due to compression⁣
👩🏽‍⚕️Hemothorax - same as above but with blood in pleural space instead of air⁣
👩🏽‍⚕️Empyema - collection of pus in the pleural cavity⁣
👩🏽‍⚕️Pleural effusion - excess fluid in the pleural space⁣
⁣
How does the chest tube work?⁣
👩🏽‍⚕️The tube is connected to a drainage system that uses gravity and possible suction to restore negative pressure and remove the excess fluid/air from the pleural cavity⁣
👩🏽‍⚕️The negative pressure allows for material to be removed ✅ but doesn’t allow air to re-enter❎⁣
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⁣
COMPONENTS OF A CHEST TUBE⁣
1️⃣ Drainage collection chamber – monitors the drainage colour and amount (normal amount is <100 cc/hr); notice that this chamber is on the right side, just below the tube that is coming from the patient⁣
2️⃣ Water seal chamber – water will fluctuate with inspiration and expiration. *If water does not fluctuate, the lung has either re-expanded or there is a kink⁣
3️⃣ Air leak monitor – excessive bubbling indicates an air leak. If your patient has a pneumothorax (air in pleural cavity), intermittent bubbling may be seen and is OK⁣
4️⃣ Suction control chamber – filled with water (remember, it’s the height of water that controls the amount of suction); bubbling is expected in this chamber as it indicates that an appropriate amount of suction is being used. Notice that this chamber is on the left side, just below the tube that is connected to the suction⁣
⁣
If you have a patient with a chest tube:⁣
❗️Avoid kinks or pressure in the tubing⁣
❗️Do not lift the drainage system above the patient’s chest because fluid may flow back to the pleural space⁣
❗️If the tube becomes dislodged, cover the area with a sterile dressing - tape 3 sides down so that air can escape but not enter

node.text: incoming nursing students — save this for your first semester 🤓

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Barbara | BSN, RN on August 06, 2021.

node.text:
BLOOD TRANSFUSION TIPS⁣
⁣⁣
⁣ ♥️ Firstly, confirm that an order & consent for the transfusion exists⁣⁣
⁣⁣
♥️ Take a baseline set of vital signs on your patient (should be within 30 minutes of the transfusion)⁣⁣
⁣⁣
♥️ Ensure that everything is prepared before you get your blood - this includes your filtered Y tubing being primed with NS, a second (and completely separate) bag of NS with the tubing primed (this is your rescue line), an patent IV (flush the IV beforehand!)⁣⁣
⁣⁣
♥️ If you’re new to transfusions = print off your hospital blood transfusion policy sheet and read it over before administering the blood so you’re well aware of the steps for administration⁣⁣
⁣⁣
♥️ Once you get the blood, hang it ASAP - it needs to be administered within 20 minutes⁣⁣
⁣⁣
♥️ BEFORE administering the blood, grab another nurse so that a double check can be performed/patient identification can be confirmed! Confirm patient name, DOB, hospital ID number, and blood type. Then confirm that the blood bag ID number matches that of the blood ID number on the paperwork given to you by the blood bank. If there are any discrepancies at all: DO NOT CONTINUE. ⁣
⁣⁣
♥️ Teach the patient about S/S of a transfusion reaction - these include fever, chills, nausea, urticaria, and bronchospasms. Advise the patient to call you immediately if they experience any of these⁣⁣
⁣⁣
♥️ Monitor your patient closely for the first 15 minutes of the transfusion - this is when reactions are most likely to happen⁣⁣
⁣⁣
♥️ If you suspect a transfusion reaction: stop the transfusion, attach your rescue line of normal saline and run it, notify the physician and blood bank, intervene according to the patient’s S/S, and monitor vital signs⁣⁣
⁣⁣
📸: @heartworkandpatients

node.text:
💊BETA BLOCKERS💊⁣
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⁣
Remember, beta blockers end in “-olol” (e.g. metoprolol, atenolol, bisoprolol, etc)⁣
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⁣
1️⃣ Class of medication: beta adrenergic blocker⁣
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⁣
2️⃣ Mechanism of action: inhibits the response to beta adrenergic stimulation. Beta blockers are cardioselective for beta1 receptors (found in the heart) with little/no effect on beta2 receptors (found in the bronchi, blood vessels, uterus, liver, urinary tract, and eye). This action blocks the hormone epinephrine, which as a result allows for the heart to beat slower and with less force. ⁣
❗️This means that HR and BP will drop with beta blocker administration❗️⁣
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⁣
3️⃣ Common uses: hypertension, arrhythmia, heart failure, myocardial infarction, and chest pain⁣
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⁣
4️⃣ Adverse effects: bradycardia, hypotension, weakness, fatigue, cool extremities⁣
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⁣
5️⃣ Warnings:⁣
👉🏼 Ischemic heart disease and angina can be exacerbated after abrupt withdrawal from metoprolol⁣
👉🏼 Beta blockers can cause myocardial depression and may precipitate heart failure and cardiogenic shock⁣
👉🏼 Beta blockers may potentiate or mask S/S of hypoglycemia in diabetics⁣
👉🏼 In patients with psychiatric illness, beta blockers may cause or exacerbate CNS depression
